org.apache.cocoon.transformation
Class CInitiateTransformer

java.lang.Object
  AbstractSAXTransformer
      org.apache.cocoon.transformation.CInitiateTransformer

public class CInitiateTransformer
extends AbstractSAXTransformer

Process another request in a new thread, continuing the current request. Declaration in sitemap: 

  <map:transformer name="cinitiate" logger="cinitiate" src="org.apache.cocoon.transformation.CInitiateTransformer"/>
Of course, you'll need to declare a cinitiate logger in logkit.xconf. Define a new logtarget: 
     <cocoon id="cinitiate">
        <filename>${context-root}/WEB-INF/logs/process.log</filename>
        <format type="cocoon">
          %7.7{priority} %{time}   [%{category}] (%{uri}) %{thread}/%{class:short}:\n%{message}\n
        </format>
        <append>false</append>
      </cocoon>
and a new category: 
     <category name="cinitiate" log-level="INFO">
       <log-target id-ref="cinitiate"/>
       <log-target id-ref="error"/>
     </category>
Usage in pipeline: 
  <map:transform type="cinitiate"/>
It will transform 'initiate' elements in the "http://apache.org/cocoon/initiate/1.0" namespace. The XML looks like this: 
  <initiate src="http://myserver/full/path/to/include.xml"
      method="GET"
      xmlns="http://apache.org/cocoon/initiate/1.0">
    <parameter name="parameter-name">parameter-value</parameter>
  </initiate>
The request will be initiated in a separate thread. The src attribute must be a complete, absolute URL, and may use any protocol that Cocoon understands (including cocoon://). If the cocoon: protocol is used, the URL is rewritten to use the protocol of the original request. This is because 'internal' requests cause weird problems (the source resolver disappears after some time). The method attribute is optional, and may be "GET" (default) or "POST". There may be zero or more <parameter> elements, which are the request parameters. The parameter value may be an XML fragment. The result of the request will be written to the log file. The CInitiate transformer will replace the 'initiate' element with a 'process' element: 
  <process src="include.xml" request="http://myserver/full/path/to/include.xml"
      output="WEB-INF/logs/process/123.out"
      id="123" status="started" xmlns=http://apache.org/cocoon/initiate/1.0"
 />
The id attribute is used to identify the process and find it in the log-file. The status attribute may be 'started' (if the thread was successfully started) or 'failed' (if the thread could not be started). The src attribute is the original URI, and the request attribute the rewritten URI. The output attribute is the path to the file, relative to the webapp context, on which the process writes its output.
